Prop: 6. The parts of Bodies on which their colours depend 
are denser then the Medium wch p[er]vades their interstices.
This will appear by considering, that the colour of a
body depends not onely on the rayes wch are incident 
p[er]pendicularly or its parts, but on those also wch are incident 
at all other Angles. And that according to the 7th Observa[cion]
a very little variac[i]on of Obliquity will change the reflected 
colour where the thinn body or Small particle is <s>rather<\s> rarer then 
the Ambient Medium, in So much that Such a Small 
particle will at diversly oblique Incidences reflect all Sorts 
of colours in So great a variety, that the colour, resulting from 
them all confusedly reflected from a heap of Such particles 
must rather be a white or grey than any other colour, or at 
best, it must be but a very imperfect and dirty colour; where[as]
if the thin body or Small particle be much denser then 
the Ambient Medium, the colours, according to the 19th Obser 
-vac[i]on, are Soe little changed by the variac[i]on of Obliquity,
that the rayes which are reflected least obliquely may 
predominate ouer the rest So much as to cause a heap of 
Such particles to appear very intensly of their colour.
It conduces also Something to this proposic[i]on, that 
according to 22th Observac[i]on, the colours exhibited by the 
Denser thin Body within the rarer are more brisque, then 
those exhibited by the rarer within the Denser.
Prop: 7th: The bignesse of the Component parts of Natural 
Bodies may be conjectured by their colours.
For Since the parts of these bodyes by Prop: 5 doe 
most probably exhibit the Same colours with a plate of equal 
thicknesse, provided they haue the Same refractive density,
and Since their parts Seeme for the most part to haue 
much the Same density with water or Glasse, as by many 
Circumstances is Obvious to Collect, to determine the Sizes 
of these parts you need onely haue recourse to the precedent 
Tables in which the thicknesse of water or Glasse exhibiting 
any colour is expressed. Thus if it be desired to know the 
Diameter of a Corpuscle, which being of equall density with 
Glasse Shall reflect Green of the third Order, the number 
17 1/2 Showes it to be about 17 1/2 / 1000000 parts of an inch.
